sections.text: Sneha Reddy: Hi Max—Sneha Reddy here. Thanks for taking a few minutes. I’ll keep this quick: I wanted to share how Terraspire Energy could tighten forecast accuracy and pipeline hygiene without replacing your CRM—just layering on top of it.
Max Chavez: Hey Sneha. Sure—what are you thinking, and how does it work with what we already have?

Sneha Reddy: Great question. The product is called Sales_Accelerator. It sits on top of Salesforce or HubSpot and uses what’s already there—stages, amounts, close dates—plus activity signals like emails, calls, meetings, and stage age. The two things most teams use first are: one, an explainable sales_forecast with commit/best-case/pipeline views; and two, automated pipeline hygiene that flags what’s missing or stale and gives reps a prioritized “fix-it” task list.
Max Chavez: Forecasting is always a sore spot. We do a lot of spreadsheet work on top of Salesforce. What’s different about your forecast?

Sneha Reddy: The difference is it’s not just “stage-based.” Sales_Accelerator combines stage data with real activity signals and benchmarks—like cycle-time norms for your segment—so it can tell you not just “this is in stage 3,” but “this has been in stage 3 too long, last touch was 12 days ago, and there’s no next meeting scheduled.” Then it rolls that into forecast views—commit, best-case, pipeline—and it’s explainable. You can click into a number and see the drivers: stage age, last touch, next meeting, and historical win rate for similar deals.
Max Chavez: Explainable is good. We’ve tried tools that spit out a number and no one trusts it. How would this fit into our weekly pipeline review?

Sneha Reddy: That’s exactly one of the common use cases. A manager runs weekly pipeline hygiene automatically: the system alerts on missing next steps, stale opps, and single-threaded deals. Instead of you chasing reps for updates, reps get an ordered queue of the top 10 actions that will most improve forecast health—things like “schedule next meeting,” “update close plan,” “add stakeholder,” or “this opp hasn’t had an outbound touch since X.”
Max Chavez: When you say “single-threaded,” you mean only one contact in the opp?

Sneha Reddy: Exactly. If a deal is progressing but there’s only one engaged contact and no evidence of broader threading, it gets flagged as higher risk. It’s not meant to be punitive—just an early warning signal so you can intervene before the quarter ends and the deal slips.
Max Chavez: Okay. We’re mid-implementation on some process changes, though. How heavy is the setup? I don’t want a six-month rollout.

Sneha Reddy: Totally fair. Sales_Accelerator is intentionally a layer—not a rip-and-replace. The baseline setup is connecting your CRM and mapping stages, fields, and activity sources. Most teams start with forecasting and hygiene alerts first, because that’s the fastest time-to-value. Then you can expand into scenario planning—like, “If we add 20 SQLs in our highest-fit segment, what’s the expected impact on pipeline coverage and expected revenue?”
Max Chavez: Scenario planning sounds interesting, but we’d need it to match how we slice the business—by segment, rep, and source. Can it do that?

Sneha Reddy: Yes. Forecast can be cut by segment, rep, and source, and it also shows stage conversion and slippage diagnostics—so you can see, for example, where deals tend to stall and which segments are most exposed to slippage. That’s useful not just for this quarter’s call, but for improving your process over time.
Max Chavez: How does it decide “this deal is at risk”? Just based on last activity?

Sneha Reddy: Activity is one major signal, but it’s multi-factor. Think: stage age versus your historical cycle-time benchmarks, whether there’s a next meeting scheduled, whether the opp is progressing through stages at a normal rate, and how similar deals have behaved historically. Then it surfaces risk drivers so your team can validate it quickly. The goal is fewer surprises at end-of-quarter—no more “it was in commit all month and then vanished.”
Max Chavez: That would be nice. Our leadership cares a lot about forecast calls being consistent across managers.

Sneha Reddy: That’s another area where this helps—consistency and transparency. Because the drivers are visible, managers aren’t each using a different mental model. And reps see the same signals, so the week-to-week changes are easier to explain.
Max Chavez: What about rep workflow? I don’t want them living in yet another tool.

Sneha Reddy: Understood. The way most teams use it is: reps get a short ordered task queue—top 10 items—so it’s lightweight. And managers get the alerts and the forecast views. We’re not trying to replace your CRM as the system of record; we’re helping it become actionable so you don’t spend the week cleaning data before leadership asks for numbers.
Max Chavez: Makes sense. We’re on Salesforce, and our activity data is a mix—some logged, some not. Does that break it?

Sneha Reddy: It doesn’t break it, but the better the activity capture, the better the signal. In practice, we start with what you have—meetings on calendar, emails, calls—then we can tighten coverage over time. Even with imperfect logging, stage age plus “next step exists” versus “no next step” tends to surface meaningful hygiene issues quickly.
Max Chavez: If we did this, what would you want from me to evaluate it properly?

Sneha Reddy: For a full evaluation, I’d suggest a 30-minute deeper session where we look at: your current forecast process, your stage definitions and cycle times, how you run weekly pipeline reviews, and what you consider “healthy” vs “risky.” If you’re open to it, we can also outline what a pilot would look like—typically one segment or one team—focused on forecast accuracy and pipeline hygiene alerts.
Max Chavez: Yeah, I’m open to that. I’d want my sales ops lead involved too.

Sneha Reddy: Perfect. If you can bring sales ops, we can make it very practical—what fields you rely on, what reports you use today, and where your biggest gaps are. Then we’ll map exactly how Sales_Accelerator would generate commit/best-case/pipeline views and the hygiene task queues your managers and reps would see.
Max Chavez: Okay. What times are you thinking?
Sneha Reddy: I can do Thursday at 11:00am PT or Friday at 2:00pm PT. Which works better for you and sales ops?
Max Chavez: Thursday at 11:00am PT should work. Send an invite and I’ll pull in our ops lead.

Sneha Reddy: Great—Thursday 11:00am PT it is. I’ll send the calendar invite and include a short agenda: current forecast workflow, pipeline hygiene pain points, and a walk-through of the explainable forecast drivers and alerting. Thanks, Max—looking forward to it.
Max Chavez: Sounds good. Talk Thursday.
